level_info.name: C++ Variables & Data Types
level_info.description: Understanding C++ variables, data types, and declarations

questions.question_text: How do you declare an integer variable in C++?
questions.explanation: In C++, you declare an integer variable using 'int' followed by the variable name.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a valid C++ variable name?
questions.explanation: Variable names can start with letters or underscores, contain letters, digits, and underscores, but cannot start with digits or be reserved keywords.

questions.question_text: What is the correct way to initialize a variable in C++?
questions.explanation: C++ supports multiple initialization syntaxes: assignment (=), direct initialization (), and uniform initialization {}.

questions.question_text: What is the size of a 'double' data type in C++?
questions.explanation: A 'double' is typically 8 bytes (64 bits) on most modern systems, providing double precision floating-point numbers.

questions.question_text: How do you declare a constant in C++?
questions.explanation: The 'const' keyword is used to declare constants in C++. Once initialized, const variables cannot be modified.

questions.question_text: What does 'auto' keyword do in C++11 and later?
questions.explanation: The 'auto' keyword allows the compiler to automatically deduce the variable's type from its initializer.

questions.question_text: Which data type is used for single characters in C++?
questions.explanation: The 'char' data type stores a single character and typically occupies 1 byte of memory.

questions.question_text: What is the difference between 'int' and 'long' in C++?
options: 'long' is at least as large as 'int'
questions.explanation: The C++ standard guarantees that 'long' is at least as large as 'int', but actual sizes are implementation-dependent.

questions.question_text: How do you declare multiple variables of the same type?
options: int a; int b; int c;
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: You can declare multiple variables either on separate lines or on the same line separated by commas.

questions.question_text: What happens to uninitialized local variables in C++?
questions.explanation: Uninitialized local variables in C++ contain garbage values (whatever was previously in that memory location). Always initialize variables.
